__data__.text:
Incorporating
 
adaptive
 
feedback
 
capability
 
to
 
Interactive
 
Videos
 
tutor
 
in
 
Project
 
Ivy
Introduction
I
 
plan
 
to
 
participate
 
in
 
the
 
Ivy
 
project
 
under
 
the
 
guidance
 
of
 
Professor
 
Ashok
 
Goel
 
in
 
the
 
Design
 
and
 
Intelligence
 
Laboratory
 
(DILab).
The
 
interactive
 
videos
 
or
 
Ivy
 
(formerly
 
known
 
as
 
the
 
“in-video”
 
tutors)
 
project
 
at
 
DILab,
 
Georgia
 
Tech,
 
is
 
an
 
AI-based
 
application
 
that
 
aims
 
to
 
make
 
online
 
education
 
videos
 
foster
 
active
 
learning
 
and
 
learning
 
by
 
doing.
 
It
 
was
 
first
 
introduced
 
in
 
the
 
Fall
 
2014
 
online
 
Knowledge-based
 
Artificial
 
Intelligence
 
(KBAI)
 
course
 
as
 
part
 
of
 
the
 
online
 
Master's
 
in
 
Computer
 
Science
 
(OMSCS)
 
program.
 
These
 
tutors
 
have
 
been
 
a
 
part
 
of
 
the
 
mode
 
of
 
instruction
 
for
 
the
 
online
 
KBAI
 
course
 
and
 
have
 
been
 
instrumental
 
in
 
making
 
KBAI
 
interactive
 
exercises
 
more
 
engaging
 
and
 
helping
 
overall
 
course
 
content
 
understanding.
 
 
Currently,
 
the
 
team
 
is
 
investigating
 
to
 
what
 
extent
 
can
 
they
 
build
 
a
 
methodology,
 
architecture
 
and
 
interface
 
or
 
“tech
 
framework”
 
for
 
interactive
 
videos
 
such
 
that
 
it
 
is
 
generalizable
 
and
 
scalable
 
for
 
online
 
courses
 
that
 
have
 
two
 
main
 
characteristics:
 
(1)
 
the
 
primary
 
audience
 
is
 
adult
 
learners,
 
and
 
(2)
 
the
 
course
 
content
 
focuses
 
on
 
skill-based
 
procedural
 
knowledge
 
learning.

__data__.text:
Research
 
Objectives
My
 
desired
 
role
 
in
 
the
 
project
 
would
 
be
 
to
 
assess
 
the
 
current
 
state
 
of
 
generalization,
 
look
 
into
 
the
 
existing
 
literature
 
on
 
that
 
front
 
and
 
use
 
edstem
 
conversations
 
as
 
a
 
means
 
of
 
guiding
 
the
 
AI
 
agent
 
to
 
learn
 
what
 
the
 
student
 
needs
 
help
 
learning
 
or
 
understanding
 
better.
 
More
 
comprehensively:
●
Literature
 
overview:
 
A
 
comprehensive
 
study
 
of
 
existing
 
studies/methodologies
 
in
 
the
 
field.
●
Explore
 
the
 
entry-points
 
for
 
the
 
interactive
 
tutor
 
i.e.
 
what
 
suggests
 
that
 
the
 
student
 
needs
 
further
 
assistance.
●
Explore/study
 
the
 
patterns
 
from
 
Edstem
 
which
 
is
 
good
 
training
 
grounds
 
for
 
the
 
interactive
 
tutor.

__data__.text:
Project
 
Timeline
Since
 
this
 
is
 
a
 
multi-semester
 
project,
 
we
 
can
 
tackle
 
long-term
 
or
 
multiple
 
problems.
 
Following
 
is
 
a
 
rough
 
estimate
 
and
 
is
 
subject
 
to
 
change:
●
3
 
weeks:
 
Literature
 
review
 
and
 
research
 
design
●
3
 
weeks:
 
Source
 
data
 
required
 
for
 
next
 
steps
●
8
 
weeks:
 
Prototype
 
a
 
proof
 
of
 
concept
 
for
 
the
 
interactive
 
tutor
●
2
 
weeks:
 
Gather
 
feedback
●
5
 
weeks:
 
Look
 
into
 
more
 
generalization
 
ideas
●
2
 
weeks:
 
Get
 
approval
 
for
 
methodologies
●
7
 
weeks:
 
Design
 
the
 
interactive
 
tutor
 
with
 
generalization
Methodologies
●
For
 
entry
 
point,
 
we
 
could
 
explore
 
having
 
straightforward
 
input
 
from
 
the
 
student,
 
since
 
that
 
resembles
 
what
 
happens
 
on
 
Ed.
●
From
 
that
 
point
 
on,
 
we
 
can
 
have
 
a
 
conversation-based
 
AI
 
agent
 
that
 
can
 
help
 
the
 
student’s
 
queries.
●
Some
 
pre-designed
 
quizzes
 
to
 
solidify
 
the
 
student’s
 
understanding
 
can
 
be
 
plugged
 
in
 
by
 
the
 
agent
 
when
 
the
 
flow
 
requires
 
such.
●
Be
 
able
 
to
 
suggest
 
additional
 
videos/wiki
 
pages
 
over
 
the
 
internet
 
for
 
further
 
reading.
●
GPT
 
like
 
behaviour
 
in
 
question
 
answering.
Expected
 
Outcomes
The
 
expected
 
outcomes
 
include
●
A
 
functioning
 
interactive
 
system
 
which
 
can
 
help
 
students
 
in
 
variable
 
(non-routine)
 
ways.
●
A
 
presentation
 
or
 
paper
 
detailing
 
the
 
results
●
Ivy
 
project
 
starting
 
to
 
be
 
incorporated
 
in
 
other
 
courses
 
would
 
be
 
a
 
good
 
outcome.
